item.title: The Passion According to G.H., 2023 - ★★
item.description: Carvalho is working so hard he ends up stiff in a way that doesn’t serve either Candido nor Lispector.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Castration Movie Anthology i. Traps, 2024 - ★★★★
item.description: For some reason I expect this to have a more shitpost feel instead of, despite all of its very online trappings, being so affecting. The scenes around Clements especially. It is a lot of movie, but far more carefully thought out than its surface messiness suggests, and it remains so close to everyone on screen in ways that are very moving.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Wake Up Dead Man, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: Like most of Johnson's work since Brick, this is clever sleight of hand, a little too in love with itself, but over half of the time he is quite good at doing this kind of thing, and this is one of his better exercises in auteurial management. Quite literally, as so much of it is about shuffling the pieces around to make it sound fresher than it is. The key decision, centering it on O’Connor’s priest more than the detective, pays off partly because O’Connor is great and partly because his feeling of personal guilt does offer the movie at least the impression of stakes. The exposition can be too much, and Brolin’s congregation is the weakest large cast of those, with only the actors with a serious role to play getting anything to do (the actresses outside of Glenn Close are especially wasted). The faith angle does give the major roles (except predictably the internet guy) something to actually play off, even if it feels like a mistake to make it about Catholics instead of Protestants; the church just feels a bit phonier than it should, but then everything in Johnson’s movies feels phony by design.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: A Girl Named Ann, 2024 - ★★½
item.description: Determinist social drama about a young drug addict trying to get herself clean while the world keeps setting new obstacles for her. This is very straightforward and has a very good lead performance, but at times it mistakes realism for punishment and puts too much focus away from her.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Let's Go Karaoke!, 2023 - ★★★½
item.description: There is something very odd about a Yamashita movie that deals with Yakuzas. It is about a young choirboy becoming a gangster karaoke coach, an absurd enough concept that Yamashita treats with seriousness and warmth. A very likable movie on dreading approaching adulthood (the idea that puberty is about to destroy the lead’s voice hangs over the movie).
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Major Tones, 2023 - ★★★
item.description: Very open and ready to use its interest in fiction forms to advance its coming of age scenario. Director Pokropek does have a very nice eye, her movie remains very low-key but animated by the certainty that the world does promise its lead a little more to come.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Renoir, 2025 - ★★½
item.description: Rough time for a family from a young girl's point of view. Aptly made, but none of the stabs at standing out from other similar movies does much for it.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Coolie, 2025 - ★★
item.description: Playacting through a series of gangster film echoes. A couple of decent action moments, but the whole movie is so uniform, it starts to drag and lose interest fast. The second half is rather weak.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Urchin, 2025 - ★★½
item.description: A not bad stab at updating British realism, but a not very interesting one either.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Die My Love, 2025 - ★★½
item.description: Impressively committed to its wavelength and does a very convincing job at establishing its leads' unstable world, even if, as usual, I'm not very taken by Ramsay's maximalist misery. The leads go all-in, if at times the movie can come off a bit too much as a set experiment for them. For something so visceral, it can be a bit studied. I like Ramsay's first two movies and hate the two comeback ones, and this one splits the difference between them, it is consistently intriguing if a little academic and safe. It is easy to admire the swing, but it ends a bit too much like a vehicle for Lawrence for its own good.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Ripples, 2023 - ★★★
item.description: A dry movie about a woman's joining a cult and its effects on her that overextends director Ogigami a little. At times, her gentle touch shows up, but the film seems to be in an uneasy position, giving her character space and letting it remain very determined. It does get better as still goes a long and has some strong scenes, but it remains never quite as good as ir is better moments.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Metro... In Dino, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description: It does make the best out of its multiple stories sliding into each other. Indeed, most of Basu's pleasure seems to be in the effort to hold them together through music and the constant movement. Very likable cast. Not all the parts are equal, and at times the strands show, but most of it is charming.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Life, 2023 - ★★★
item.description: Long and bloated, but it is very successful in its movement from one character to another. Miray Daner's lead is among the best rendered in the Demirkubuz's movies I've seen, and the general sense of everyone stuck in a stratified society logic does register strongly.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Batguano Returns: Roben on the Road, 2025 - ★★★½
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: Batguano Returns: Roben on the Road
item.description: A bitter and melancholic road movie that seems to act as an escape and a meeting at the same time. Teixeira's Robin is less the tropicalist Butthead of the original movie than a venue for diaristic fiction that always remains at a limit, spent but defiant. The first movie was about wasting away around consumed cultural detritus, this second is about the pieces left by a world that overloaded on it. So, the movie seems to exist in the space between them, from the playful sadness of the original appropriations to something more upfront and uneasy. It wouldn't work without Teixeira's performance, as he is isolated and reacting by himself to the world at large for huge chunks of it, and very few people could pull it off, but he remains one of Brazilian cinema's more interesting presences.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: 1st Kiss, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: High-concept Japanese romantic fantasy with marriage, death, and time travel. Director Tsukahara mostly uses the scenario to observe a relationship at start and end. The balance between the presence of dread and longing is good, and it is becomes very affecting when it moves past its plotting.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Ariel, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description: Patiño made a short with Matias Piñero and actress Augustina Muñoz a few years ago, and Ariel plays a lot like he is making his version of one of the movies the two did together, even bringing Muñoz in the center. Some good use of the Azores and the mix of fiction and the presence of history is successful. Patiño's eye remains great, and for the time he does integrate actors well into it.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Across the Furious Sea, 2023 - ★★½
item.description: Ambitious, messy, and very bloated. I liked it when it made me think of lesser Soi Cheang, not so much when it felt like a Korean thriller. The 140+ minute length is ridiculous, and one might argue part of the point. A few images do register. It is stronger when it is playing towards its more engrossing thriller moments and weaker when articulating character.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Yellow Loves, 1958 - ★★★
item.description: It is good to know that 20 year old Jean Rollin was already able to turn some shots of a beach and lines of poetry and make sure a man could disappear there doomed at any given moment.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Contact Lens, 2024 - ★★
item.description: Carefully controlled and clever, but it exhausts itself very early.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Youth (Homecoming), 2024 - ★★★½
item.description: This feels like a necessary complement for the project, moving the focus away from labor relationships and getting to leisure/home and the ways the former affect them. A dramatic payoff on the increasingly pointed urgency displayed in the observation of the earlier entries.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Along Came Love, 2023 - ★★
item.description: Quillévéré is a talented enough filmmaker for a few scenes to register, but this is mostly a misfire. It never finds a good hand for its drama, and Lacoste's performance, on which a lot of the film hinges, doesn't work.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Love in the Big City, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: It doesn't always manage to balance all of its material, but the central platonic relationship does give it a good center. Fine leads performances and hits an effective, affectionate tone.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: L'Aventura, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: An extension of Letourneur's earlier Voyage to Italy (I'm now trying to guess which Italian classic she will lift the title for the last one), I like this one better as it is doing more things, although it also makes the earlier one stronger, as I think it makes clear some of the efforts of locating fiction in these characters in movement through a foreign space. Very good actors, and the interplay between the French naturalism and the deliberate construction is well deployed throughout.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Blue Trail, 2025 - ★★
item.description: It coasts on a good Weinberg performance and the natural landscape, but it is rather thin dramatically, and the world it settles in seems so narrow. Mascaro's previous dystopic movie, Divino Amor, had more urgency and a strong sense of what it wanted to be.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Happyend, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: It is probably not fair to Happyend that I saw Typhoon Club a couple of months ago, as it suggests a more overblown version of it, but there should be more current movies that make me think of Shinji Somai. It is stronger when its teenage alienation feels more grounded, and at times it does feel too big for its own good, but most of the scenes among the young cast are quite good.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Flat Girls, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: Pretty good Thai coming-of-age film about two lifelong friends who live in the same place and the multiple difficulties that come between them. Almost everything to do with their relationship is very good, and director Jirassaya Wongsutin generally has a good touch. She also does some good work towards keeping the movie rooted at the main location, even if the film is at its weakest in its more overt efforts at social commentary. The feeling of the light melancholia and the central performances more than carry it.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Evil Puddle, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description: Motern is doing some kind of Shyamalan-King mashup. Very enjoyable and eccentric, as is most of their work. Funny and as the situation spreads, it does make the dramatic stakes matter. The emphasis on community means this is the least Farley-centric of their movies while actually offering him one of his best opportunities to play on his persona. Some of the town's reactions to the evil puddle scenes have an obvious echo of the pandemic, and it is interesting to observe that the movie's affectionate tone makes the satirical jabs play much better. Extra points because my friend Taylor is in it.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Little, Big, and Far, 2024 - ★★½
item.description: I'm not sure the more cosmic framework mixes that well with Cohen usual interests. The film ends up a little scattered among the large scope it is trying to cover. At times, it does suggest a stronger movie.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Bad Girl, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description: Great central character and performance. I appreciate this is very honest about all the difficulties about being a young woman in Indian society while keeping itself warm and far from art movie territory. I don't think all parts work as well as others and the end ties things up a little too tight, but director Bharath has a very nice touch and the more intimate scenes among women are lovely.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Running Man, 2025 - ★½
item.description: Passable enough crap, more or less, until Powell gets into Jones' car, pretty much unbearable strident and toothless from that point on. The stabs at satire are terrible, the action is ok if far from inspired, the not-quite future isn't that well imagined, and it wastes far too many good actors. If one wants to see proto Verhovian take in similar material, Robert Shackey's The Prize of Peril (King's main inspiration for his novel) was done very well in Germany in 1970 (The Million Game) and France in 1983 (The Prize of Peril); this one is as bankrupt as the Schwarzenegger version.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Custom, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: Director Teixeira is a longtime mutual, so I was curious about this. As a collection of horror images, this is effectively chilling and upsetting. It hits the same notes often enough to dilute a little of the effect even at around 75 minutes, but it is always good to watch some current horror that is after something closer to its influence instead of just dropping them as a reference. The most evil vibes of anything I've seen since Paul Duane's All You Need is Death, so I crack up that the one positive review I saw was Paul's.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Sorry, Baby, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: Nicely written and observed, some solid use of Victor's comic insincts, while the general arc remain less satisfying than its better parts.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Trap House, 2025 - ★★
item.description: Impressively, proudly stupid. At times, that's a plus, but so much of this is uninteresting. Also, Bautista is too fun a movie presence to be playing a concerned adult.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Sentimental Value, 2025 - ★★
item.description: Great Skaasgard performance, and a couple of the scenes between the sisters have some force to them; everything else is very tidy and careful throughout. Pretend messy emotions that have been safely contained. The ending is especially terrible. It is better when it flirts with comedy of manipulation (the idea that Skaarsgard sees actors as phony family members, so he tries to go along with using Fanning as a replacement of Rainsave, in particular). As far as movies that seem to be there to flatten actors' narcissism and only exist between November and March go, at least Jay Kelly comes from a mind that got deranged from too much time in his privileged cocoon. Credit where it is due, it is mostly properly titled big movie of the year.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Blind Horizon, 2003 - ★★½
item.description: Not bad low budget paranoid fiction. The amnesia investigation plot is obvious, but cast is good at time the movie does make its more unstable elements work on its favor.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Blazing Fists, 2025 - ★★
item.description: I haven't seen a new Takeshi Miike film in a few years, so it is always good to check on him from time to time. I can't say this one was very rewarding, like most of his work from the second half of the last decade, this shows him working close to a more slick mainstream genre cinema, but it lacks the drive of his better movies like this, and it is very somber instead of playful, as his more successful stabs at melodramatic material used to be.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Fragments for Venus, 2025 - ★★
item.description: It does the job in a very closed off and studied manner.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Air, 2023 - ★★★½
item.description: An affecting and large war spectacle about female flight pilots on the Leningrad front from the talented Alexei German Jr. Some great war scenes with excellent plane action. The realities of women on the war front are dutifully observed, as is the general sense of resilience. German Jr. can do harsh as well as he can do excitement. The accumulated loss has power. The image near the end of a shot plane slowly approaching the inevitable, for instance. War is a tough negotiation with death that states win and people lose.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: A Ladder, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description: Barley secretly a very good "narrative" filmmaker, one always engaged in what he is going to do next even as it follows what feels by the end an inevitable logic.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Left-Handed Girl, 2025 - ★★
item.description: The perils of festival naturalism. Neither the light nor the heavy moments land very convincing.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Silent Witnesses, 2023 - ★★★
item.description: A return to images from Colombian silent film reorganized in its own work. This was the last project the great Luis Ospina worked on, which adds another dimension to it. Some great images recovered. Very much for those interested in early cinema and what its images manage to suggest.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Super Happy Forever, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: Hong-lite Japanese drama about finding and losing people. The casual filmmaking plays against the more rigid structure, and the resort setting is very well used.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Second Life, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: One of the most tonally odd recent movies out of HK/China. The setup, woman comes off prison and reunites with long lost blind son who is actually a killer, is used so it can shift emotional registers constantly. The central relationship is affecting, and director Chris Huo can be trusted to deliver some very well executed action when the movie settles into it. A very good showcase for veteran character actress Yuen Qiu.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Game Changer, 2025 - ★★★
item.description: It doesn't hold as a narrative, and the hit-to-miss ratio on all the over the top moments isn't very good, but it goes all in with a lot of conviction and is easy to admire in spots.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Shadow's Edge, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description: Ostensibly, a mainland remake of the Milkyway survillance thriller Eye in the Sky retrofitted into a late-career Jackie Chan vehicle. It is fairly overblown (it runs 140 minutes for some reason and has so many characters and plot points), but it is a pretty good collection of cat-and-mouse games, chases, and close-quarters brawls set around intergenerational tensions. Chan is, of course, brought back from retirement to teach the kids how to do things after the police figure out the bad guys knew how to hack and manipulate their computer system (see governments, do not trust AI to run your surveillance state). He is very good in this, far more somber than usual, with little in the way of jokes, although a decent amount of sentiment as he bonds with the daughter of his former partner. He gets to fight his fair share, if in a far more grounded way than usual, and the movie incorporates his aging rather well. Director Larry Yang helmed the not-good but sometimes likable meta stuntman comedy Ride On, Chan did a few years ago, and this plays on some of those themes in a more straightforward manner. Because time has stopped in Hong Kong-adjacent movies (this is a mainland production set in Macau), Tony Leung Ka Fai is back as the master criminal, and he remains effectively menacing even if it is rather silly to see him taking on rooms full of men at 67. This has flaws, but Jackie Chan movies should not be this enjoyable in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Jay Kelly, 2025 - ★★
item.description: It is no Deconstructing Harry. The idea of centering it around Clooney while making the emotional stakes on Sandler for the most part doesn’t work. It has a lot of odd choices, but so few of them pay off, and it is so bloated. It is probably better appreciated as a perverse attempt to get Netflix to finance an eccentric phony art object, and at least it is never as bad as White Noise. Far from one of the better uses of Sandler in one of his non-Happy Madison movies, but the movie desperately needs his warmth.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Familiar Touch, 2024 - ★★★
item.description: Very effective taken by its detailed procedural. Its success is linked to how it manages to remain intimate while observing her loss from a distance, which does make the give-and-take between good/bad days come off strongly. Sometimes it verges a little closer to naturalist humanism that pops on festival movies too much, but most of this handles it with care.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: The Volunteers: The Battle of Life and Death, 2024 - ★★★
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: The Volunteers: The Battle of Life and Death
item.description: It is so funny that Chen Kaige turned 70 and became a specialist in large-scale military action. This is overlong and a little too heavy to move gracefully; there are so many scenes of soldiers sacrificing their lives as big music plays over, but most of it is battle, and those scenes are massive and greatly executed. A mix of Chen Kaige's good eye for composition and sense of scope. Very exciting and does make the death toll count.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Havoc, 2025 - ★★½
item.description: Lots of gunfire, the actions gets samey as it often does in Evans movies and he will probably always be the kind of artist that thinks his brutality has more depth than it does. More punishing than exciting, but have its moments.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Curbing Violence, 2024 - ★★½
item.description: Some solid action and a hateful villain, but China DTV specialist Qin Pengfei feels very ill suited for this one.
item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: John Ford ranked
item.description:
So I ran out of John Ford films I had access to, it had to happen some time.


I've seen more Ford features than any other director including almost all of his talkies except for The Brat, his second Korea doc and his Vietnam one (I'm also missing some of his shorts as well as his second half hour for Screen Directors Playhouse). Ford has his ocassional minor films (it would be impossible not to given how prolific he was) but I don't know anyone who has directed as many great ones. The first 58 films on this list are at least very good (and 17 after that all solid) and only the final four are not worth to bother beyond the more hardcore completists.

I try to avoid movies that remain only in short fragments and How The West Was Won is standing for Ford's The Civil segment only.

  1. Wagon Master
  2. How Green Was My Valley
  3. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

item.dc:creator: Sample User

item.title: Walter Hugo Khouri Ranked
item.description:
Today marks twenty years since Walter Hugo Khouri passed away. He was one of Brazil’s most important directors from the late 50s until at least the early 80s, but he often seems in danger of being forgotten, perhaps because he doesn’t fit any official Brazilian cinema historiographies. He was more successful commercially and critically than most of his well-known peers, although he did sometimes feel like he had the wrong friends and enemies, and was certainly far more influential among young Brazilian filmmakers than given credit (even Glauber Rocha, who wrote very negatively about his movies in the 60s, reportedly arranged a screening of his first short, Patio, because he wanted feedback from “Brazil’s greatest director”). Despite his reputation as a stuffy Antonioni-lite filmmaker, he took far more chances than is given credit (horror movies, westerns, odd experiments, a first-person movie). Khouri was in the Cannes competition three times, although I've never seen him mentioned in a foreign context. A friend of mine worked in one of his last movies, a Brazilian/Italian co-production starring Ben Gazarra, and he tells about how the great American actor was unengaged through the early days of shooting, clearly regarding it as a paycheck, until someone from the production arranged a private screening of Khouri movies for Gazarra in his off day. On Monday, he showed up on set, calling Khouri "il maestro", game for anything, very focused, and even offering to stay for a few extra days for free if the director wanted some reshoots. Movies can be magic, and they sure can leave an impression.

  1. The Palace of Angels
  2. The Amorous Ones
  3. The Burning Body
  4. Strange Encounter
  5. Paixão e Sombras
  6. Men and Women
  7. Invitation to Pleasure
  8. As Feras
  9. Daughters of Fire
  10. I

...plus 13 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: Dario Argento ranked
item.description:
No one has murder people as artfully as Argento did between 1970 and 2001 and few have work towards destabilize with as much power as he did. A master of color, madness and lens that distort reality.

First 13 entries all vary between all timers and very good. 14-16 are only half inspired, but more fun than not. The bottom is for the completist faithful.

item.title: Favorite Non Milkyway Post Handover Hong Kong Films
item.description:
Because Johnnie To so dominates cinephile discourse about Post Handover Hong Kong Cinema seems like a good idea to shine a light in on other films from the local industry.

A few rules:
The list is in some sort of preferential order but it is very loose. It means #2 is better than #22 which is better than #42 but if I do it again I have no idea weather #22 would be ahead or behind #21 or #23.
The List covers 1997-2012 period. Films from 2013-2014 were excluded; The crisis in the local film industry started a bit before 1997 but the Handover feels like a good point to separate the production;
I did included Chinese films by HK directors as it is increasily hard to separate them, but not Chinese films that use local talent like Lust Caution.

  1. Time and Tide
  2. King of Comedy
  3. 2046
  4. From the Queen to the Chief Executive
  5. The Longest Summer
  6. Made in Hong Kong
  7. Kung Fu Hustle
  8. Happy Together
  9. Durian Durian
  10. After This Our Exile

...plus 90 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: My Ballot for LoveHKFilm Best Hong Kong films of 2010s poll
item.description:
Kozo from LoveHKFilm did their best of the decade poll a few months ago and finally finish posting it this week (the results are here). I had misplaced my ballot, but Kozo was nice enough to DM it back to me. So here for posterity with the caveats that I went two weeks unsure if I had or not voted for a dozen titles and we have reached a point when definition of Hong Kong/Mainland film have become very hard (#3 here is not an HK film by any stretch but it was on Kozo's master list and I couldn't resist) this might be the last decade a pool like this one is even possible.

  1. Life Without Principle
  2. SPL 2: A Time for Consequences
